channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-11276] Add back support for running ChaosMonkey as standalone tool
item.description: According to the ref guide, it was once possible to run ChaosMonkey as a standalone tool against a deployed cluster. After 0.94, this is no longer possible.
item.summary: Add back support for running ChaosMonkey as standalone tool

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Uploading the initial patch. The standalone tool is added back as org.apache.hadoop.hbase.chaos.utils.ChaosMonkeyRunner

Have tested the tool in a distributed cluster and confirmed it works. Here is the usage:

$./bin/hbase org.apache.hadoop.hbase.chaos.utils.ChaosMonkeyRunner -h

15/07/17 02:08:08 INFO Configuration.deprecation: hadoop.native.lib is deprecated. Instead, use io.native.lib.available

usage: bin/hbase org.apache.hadoop.hbase.chaos.utils.ChaosMonkeyRunner <options>

Options:

 -familyName <arg>            Family name in the test to run chaos monkey against

 -h,--help                    Show usage

 -m,--monkey <arg>            Which chaos monkey to run

 -monkeyProps <arg>           The properties file for specifying chaos monkey properties.

 -t,--monkeyRunTime <arg>   How much milliseconds to run the chaos monkey, 1800000 by default

 -tableName <arg>             Table name in the test to run chaos monkey against
Reassigning to Li, who's way ahead of me on this.
Yes please.

For the patch, it should not extend IT, since that means that it might get run by the IntegrationTestsDriver. Better to just do a standalone tool. Previously it was the case that you just start it, and it runs until it is killed. Not sure adding run time is needed.
Update patch according to review comments.

This will eat up the CPU. Can you do smt like while(true)

{ Threads.sleep(10000) } 


+    while (true)

+      ;// loop here until got killed

These should not be needed. We can always assume a distributed cluster. 


    util.initializeCluster(isDistributed ? 1 : this.NUM_SLAVES_BASE);

+    if (!isDistributed) {

+      util.startMiniMapReduceCluster();

+    }

Also this: 


+  protected int NUM_SLAVES_BASE = 3; // number of slaves when running test with mini cluster

Did you test this with and without table / cfs ?

Did you test this w/ and w/o table/cfs?

Done testing w/ table/cfs, but not w/o. Will add some codes do creating schema thing if table/cfs not given

About the start minicluster part, I used the codes to run a local test in my eclipse, and thought user could get a glance of how ChaosMonkey runs w/o a real cluster. However, after testing I found if in a non-eclipse environment we also need some env-setup work to make it run locally, so will remove the local-mode support following your suggestion.

About the while true line, will apply the change.

Please help review the new version patch.
With the new patch have tested both w/ and w/o table/cf option using SlowDeterministicMonkey, JFYI

We don't need createSchema(). The monkey can optionally get the table / cf to do action on, but it should not try to create the table. It should assume that table will get created from the test or it already exists.

The table/cf is truly optional, but there would be a default value for them in the tool, since Actions like SplitRandomRegionOfTableAction require a table to operate on. IMHO, if we require user to make sure the testing table/cf already exists before running monkeys, then table/cf shouldn't be optional, or if we keep it as is, we will need the createSchema method to create the table when it doesn't exist.

Enis Soztutar, What's your opinion?

The table/cf is truly optional, but there would be a default value for them in the tool

Not necessarily. Not all monkeys do table actions. For example serverKillingMonkey. That is why having the table optional is important. In case monkey does not use a table, it is fine to pass null or some non-existing table.

IMHO, if we require user to make sure the testing table/cf already exists before running monkeys, then table/cf shouldn't be optional, or if we keep it as is, we will need the createSchema method to create the table when it doesn't exist.

What is the point of creating an empty table and doing operations on them from CM? CM runner should just assume the table will be created from the concurrently running test. It is fine if table does not exists since CM will fail the table action, but it will not affect correctness.

I was thinking that actions like move random region will not be tested in monkeys like SlowDeterministicMonkey if table not exist, but you're right that operating on empty means nothing either.

Will remove createSchema method in the new patch, thanks for the comments Enis Soztutar
Update the patch to remove createSchema
Thanks Yu. Will commit after hadoopqa run.

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12746259/HBASE-11276_v4.patch
against master branch at commit 5ec5552be0534dbf4b07ef6607741ae6f9ab0495.
ATTACHMENT ID: 12746259

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 5 new or modified tests.

+1 hadoop versions. The patch compiles with all supported hadoop versions (2.4.0 2.4.1 2.5.0 2.5.1 2.5.2 2.6.0 2.7.0)

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 protoc. The applied patch does not increase the total number of protoc compiler warnings.

+1 javadoc. The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

+1 checkstyle. The applied patch does not increase the total number of checkstyle errors

+1 findbugs. The patch does not introduce any new Findbugs (version 2.0.3) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

+1 site. The mvn post-site goal succeeds with this patch.

+1 core tests. The patch passed unit tests in .

-1 core zombie tests. There are 2 zombie test(s): at org.apache.camel.component.jetty.jettyproducer.HttpJettyProducerRecipientListCustomThreadPoolTest.testRecipientList(HttpJettyProducerRecipientListCustomThreadPoolTest.java:40)
at org.apache.camel.test.spring.CamelSpringTestSupport.doCreateApplicationContext(CamelSpringTestSupport.java:90)
at org.apache.camel.test.spring.CamelSpringTestSupport.doPreSetup(CamelSpringTestSupport.java:80)
at org.apache.camel.test.junit4.CamelTestSupport.setUp(CamelTestSupport.java:237)

Test results: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/14855//testReport/
Release Findbugs (version 2.0.3) warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/14855//artifact/patchprocess/newFindbugsWarnings.html
Checkstyle Errors: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/14855//artifact/patchprocess/checkstyle-aggregate.html

Console output: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/14855//console

This message is automatically generated.
I don't think the zombie tests are caused by change in this jira since we're simply adding a standalone tool and should have no impact on existing tests.
I've committed this to 1.0+ (does not compile with 0.98). I've changed the package name to be util to be consistent with the rest of packages.Thanks Yu Li for the patch.
Now, we have to update the documentation in the book about the tool.
Thanks Enis Soztutar, here is the patch for 0.98
Yes, and maybe we could use HBASE-14084 to do this
